title: A systematic review of childhood maltreatment and DNA methylation: candidate gene and epigenome-wide approaches
affiliations: Initiative on Stress, Trauma, and Resilience, Department of Psychiatry and Human Behavior, Warren Alpert Medical School, Brown University, Providence, RI, USA
Bradley/Hasbro Children's Research Center, E. P. Bradley Hospital, East Providence, RI, USA
Laboratory for Clinical and Translational Neuroscience, Butler Hospital, Providence, RI, USA
Center for Behavioral and Preventive Medicine, The Miriam Hospital, Providence, RI, USA
background: Childhood maltreatment is a major risk factor for chronic and severe mental and physical health problems, and epigenetic changes may serve as mechanisms of disease.
hypotheses: Maltreatment is associated with epigenetic changes that may subsequently serve as mechanisms of disease.
major_findings: Childhood maltreatment is associated with altered DNA methylation in both children and adults, but findings show considerable variability across studies and genes.
In children, maltreatment is associated with higher methylation of NR3C1 and lower methylation of FKBP5, while in adults, findings are inconsistent across studies.
Epigenome-wide studies suggest that maltreatment is associated with widespread methylation changes across the genome, but findings vary across studies and samples.
Childhood adversity is associated with accelerated epigenetic aging in both children and adults, but findings are not consistently replicated across studies.
